general: This law makes rules about how much money people and businesses must pay to the government when they buy things from other countries. It also changes some existing laws so that they work better after the UK leaves the EU. The law helps the government collect taxes and make sure that everyone pays their fair share.

series.short: "Duty Charges on Goods Removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation outlines the duty of customs charged on goods removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain.
* Simplified point 2: The duty is charged if the goods are not domestic goods or are at risk of being moved into the European Union.
* Simplified point 3: The Treasury can make regulations to determine the matters related to the charging of duty under section 40A, such as the amount of duty charged and the circumstances in which goods are chargeable to duty.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can also provide for the application of provisions made by or under the customs and excise Acts to duty under section 40A or to goods removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations can impose checks, controls, and administrative processes in connection with the removal of goods to Northern Ireland from Great Britain.
* Simplified point 6: The regulations can regulate the unloading, landing, movement, and removal of goods on their removal to Northern Ireland from Great Britain, including restrictions on the places in which such goods may enter Northern Ireland.
* Simplified point 7: The section also defines expressions used in provision made by or under this section or section 40A that are defined for the purposes of Part 1 of the legislation.

series.short: "UK's Duty-Free Imports: Regulatory Framework for Northern Ireland"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is allowing goods to be imported into Northern Ireland without paying duty, as long as they are not "qualifying Northern Ireland goods."
* Simplified point 2: The government can make regulations to determine which goods are chargeable to duty and the amount of duty to be charged.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can also specify the circumstances under which duty is not chargeable, such as if the goods are being imported for a specific purpose or if they are being imported from a specific country.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can also provide for the application of Union customs legislation to goods imported into Northern Ireland, and for the recovery of any duty that has been overpaid or underpaid.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations can also provide for the imposition of checks, controls, and administrative processes in connection with the removal of goods from Northern Ireland to Great Britain.

* Simplified point 1: The Taxation (Post-transition Period) Act 2020 makes changes to Value Added Tax (VAT) rules in Northern Ireland to align with the Protocol on Ireland/Northern Ireland in the Withdrawal Agreement.
* Simplified point 2: The Act inserts new Schedules 9ZA and 9ZB into the Value Added Tax Act 1994 to provide for VAT charges on goods in Northern Ireland and to make modifications to the VAT rules for goods moving between Northern Ireland and member states.
* Simplified point 3: Part 1 of Schedule 2 amends VATA 1994 to include the new Schedules and makes further amendments to the Act, while Part 2 of Schedule 2 makes amendments to other legislation to ensure consistency with the amendments made by Part 1.
* Simplified point 4: The Act ensures that any orders or regulations made under the repealed provisions continue to have effect as if made under the re-enacted provisions, with any necessary modifications.

series.short: "UK Excise Duty Legislation for Goods Removed to Northern Ireland"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislation states that excise duty is charged on goods removed from Great Britain to Northern Ireland.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation outlines specific excise duty provisions that apply to various goods, such as spirits, beer, and wine, and requires that the goods be set aside for a chargeable use before they can be removed to Northern Ireland.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also covers special procedures for the removal of road fuel gas to Northern Ireland, and defines "relevant excise duty provision" for the purposes of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation references the Union excise directive and Union customs legislation, which are important for understanding the context and scope of the Act.

series.short: "UK Customs and Excise Laws Extended to Northern Ireland Post-Brexit"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation allows for the application of customs and excise laws to goods removed from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, as if the goods were imported into the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The Treasury can make regulations to modify the application of customs and excise laws to goods subject to duty under section 4(1), and these regulations can be annulled by a resolution of the House of Commons.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "the customs and excise Acts" is provided, and "relevant excise duty provision" is defined as any provision in the customs and excise Acts that applies to the importation of goods.
* Simplified point 4: This section and section 4 of the legislation only apply to removals of goods to Northern Ireland from Great Britain that commence on or after IP completion day.
* Simplified point 5: For the purposes of this section, a removal of goods commences when the goods are dispatched from the place in Great Britain from which they are removed, or when an aircraft or vessel carrying the goods is scheduled to depart from an airport or port in Great Britain.

series.short: "Insurance Premium Tax Liability: No Arrangements in Place"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation deals with the liability of the insured in certain cases, specifically when there are no arrangements in place regarding insurance premium tax for a particular country or territory.
* Simplified point 2: The section outlines the condition for the insured to be liable for insurance premium tax, which is the absence of arrangements in relation to the country or territory relating to insurance premium tax that have been made under an Order in Council under section 173 of the Finance Act 2006.
* Simplified point 3: The section also specifies that the arrangements must contain provisions of a kind mentioned in subsection (2)(a) and (b) of that section, which relates to the taxation of insurance premiums.

series.short: "UK State Aid Rectification Measure: Removing Loan Relationship Exemption"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the legislation allows for the recovery of unlawful state aid given to controlled foreign companies.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation makes provision for the charging of amounts under Part 9A of TIOPA 2010 (the CFC charge) as if one of the exemptions in Chapter 9 of that Part (exemptions for profits from qualifying loan relationships) had not applied, in order to comply with a European Commission decision on state aid.
* Simplified point 3: The European Commission decision (EU) 2019/1352, dated 2 April 2019, ruled that the CFC Group Financing Exemption implemented by the United Kingdom was not in line with EU state aid rules, and this legislation aims to rectify that by removing the exemption for profits from qualifying loan relationships.

series.short: "Taxation Legislation: Commencement Dates and Regulatory Powers"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation defines abbreviations used in the Act and specifies the commencement date for various provisions of the Act.
* Simplified point 2: The commencement date for different provisions of the Act are staggered, with some provisions coming into force on the day the Act is passed, while others will come into force on January 1, 2021, or at a later date to be appointed by the Treasury through regulations.
* Simplified point 3: The Treasury has the power to make regulations to provide for consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional, transitory or saving provisions in connection with the coming into force of any provision of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The Act can be cited as the Taxation (Post-transition Period) Act 2020.

series.short: "Removal of Exemption for Qualifying Loan Relationships and Recovery of Unlawful State Aid Provisions in UK Tax Law"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation removes the exemption for profits from qualifying loan relationships in order to comply with a European Commission decision on state aid.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation allows for the recovery of unlawful state aid given to controlled foreign companies.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation makes provision for the charging of amounts under Part 9A of TIOPA 2010 (the CFC charge) as if one of the exemptions in Chapter 9 of that Part had not applied.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation defines abbreviations used in the Act and specifies the commencement date for various provisions of the Act.
* Simplified point 5: The Treasury has the power to make regulations to provide for consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional, transitory or saving provisions in connection with the coming into force of any provision of the Act.

summary:
The Taxation (Post-transition Period) Act 2020 simplifies complex taxation laws in the UK post-Brexit. It focuses on three main areas: duty charges on goods removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain, regulatory framework for Northern Ireland, and taxation changes in Northern Ireland. Key points include:

1. Duty charges on goods removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain: The act outlines the duty of customs charged on goods removed to Northern Ireland from Great Britain, with specific provisions for alcoholic liquids, tobacco products, and hydrocarbon oil.
2. Regulatory framework for Northern Ireland: The act provides for the imposition of checks, controls, and administrative processes in connection with the removal of goods to Northern Ireland from Great Britain.
3. Taxation changes in Northern Ireland: The act aligns Value Added Tax (VAT) rules in Northern Ireland with the Protocol on Ireland/Northern Ireland in the Withdrawal Agreement, and includes new Schedules 9ZA and 9ZB to provide for VAT charges on goods in Northern Ireland.
4. UK customs and excise laws extended to Northern Ireland: The act allows for the application of customs and excise laws to goods removed from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, as if the goods were imported into the UK.
5. Insurance premium tax liability: No arrangements in place: The act deals with the liability of the insured in certain cases where there are no arrangements in place regarding insurance premium tax for a particular country or territory.
6. UK state aid rectification measure: Removing loan relationship exemption: The act allows for the recovery of unlawful state aid given to controlled foreign companies by removing the exemption for profits from qualifying loan relationships.
7. Taxation legislation: Commencement dates and regulatory powers: The act defines abbreviations used in the act, specifies the commencement date for various provisions, and gives the Treasury power to make regulations to provide for consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional, transitory or saving provisions.
